title: 113_s2781
content: The "Student Visa Integrity Act" defines terms like SEVIS and SEVP, increases criminal penalties under title 18, and introduces an accreditation requirement. SEC. 4. ACCREDITATION REQUIREMENT. Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to define 'accredited college, university, or language training program' as institutions accredited by a recognized accrediting agency. SEC. 5. OTHER ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS. Section 214(m) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require accreditation of academic institutions for certain purposes, with the Secretary of Homeland Security having the discretion to waive this requirement for accredited colleges, universities, or language training programs if they meet certain criteria. The Immigration and Nationality Act now requires accreditation of academic institutions for specific purposes, with the Secretary of Homeland Security able to waive this requirement for accredited colleges, universities, or language training programs under certain conditions. SEC. 6. PENALTIES FOR FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH SEVIS REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Section 641 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 is amended to impose penalties for failure to comply with SEVIS reporting requirements, including monetary fines and suspension of authority to issue Form I-20. Immediate Withdrawal of SEVP Certification: Amends Section 641(d) of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to immediately withdraw certification if there is reasonable suspicion of fraud by an owner or designated school official at an approved educational institution. The Secretary has the authority to immediately suspend certification and access to SEVIS without prior notification. Additionally, individuals convicted of fraud related to the SEVP may face permanent disqualification. Individuals convicted of fraud related to the Visitor Program (SEVP) may be permanently disqualified from filing future petitions or holding any management role in US educational institutions enrolling nonimmigrant alien students. SEC. 8. BACKGROUND CHECKS. SEC. 8. BACKGROUND CHECKS. Amends Section 641(d) of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 to include a background check requirement for designated school officials or those granted access to SEVIS. Individuals must be US nationals or lawful permanent residents and undergo a thorough background check by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The individual's criminal and sex offender history, as well as their immigration status, are reviewed for background checks. It is required that the individual has passed the background check and has no violations of US immigration law. The individual must pass a background check and online training course on SEVP and SEVIS to serve as an interim designated school official. The Secretary will review Form I-20 issued by an interim designated school official who fails the background check. A fee will be collected from approved schools for background checks, equal to the average cost incurred by the Secretary. The amendment will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 9 of the Act prohibits uncertified flight schools from issuing Form I-20 to alien students seeking visas. Certification by the Secretary and FAA is required. SEC. 10 addresses the revocation of accreditation. SEC. 10 addresses the revocation of accreditation, requiring accrediting agencies to notify relevant authorities of any denial, withdrawal, suspension, or termination of accreditation, leading to immediate withdrawal from SEVP and SEVIS access. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a report within 180 days detailing the risk assessment strategy for identifying and taking action against schools and officials aiding in visa fraud. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a report within 180 days detailing the risk assessment strategy for identifying and taking action against schools and officials aiding in visa fraud, including processes for resource allocation, school eligibility verification, monitoring of licensing and accreditation status, and certification of flight schools. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report on risk assessment strategies for identifying visa fraud involving schools and officials. This includes procedures for resource allocation, school eligibility verification, monitoring licensing and accreditation status, and certifying flight schools. Additionally, procedures for coordination among SEVP, the Counterterrorism and Criminal Exploitation Unit, and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement field offices, as well as criteria for referring potentially criminal cases from SEVP to the counterterrorism and intelligence community, have been established. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to complete the deployment of SEVIS II within 2 years of the enactment of the Act.
